articles.title: About this site
articles.contents:
Welcome to the ‘About’ page!
My name is Sai Gottemukkula, and I’m currently a rising junior at
Lexington High School. I enjoy learning about tech, as well as biking
with my friends, and playing tennis whenever I can.
About the site
I chose to do a project based on the Coronavirus pandemic because it
was a global event that completely changed the lives of the current
generation, from education to jobs, and I felt like I would have done a
disservice to all the people that it affected if I did not select the
virus as my topic.
Contact links
E-mail: saigthefirst@gmail.com
Github: https://github.com/SaiGottemukkula

articles.title: Actual vs Probable Cases
articles.description: To analyze the accuracy of four states
articles.contents:
Something that I rarely see explored in the context of COVID-19 is
how prediction models and AI are used to predict the number of probable
cases. The results that I got were quite surprising!



The graph above shows the confirmed cases for four different
states.



Here, the graph shows the probable cases for the sames
states, on the same day.
Analysis
As you can see, the graphs show that the probable cases aren’t
exactly very accurate. In fact, they’re off by thousands of cases! This
shows that our predictions can use some improvements.
(Disease Control and Prevention 2022)



Disease Control, Centers for, and Prevention. 2022. United States
COVID-19 Cases and Deaths by State over Time. Centers for Disease
Control and Prevention. https://data.cdc.gov/Case-Surveillance/United-States-COVID-19-Cases-and-Deaths-by-State-o/9mfq-cb36.

articles.title: Coronavirus Deaths vs Cases
articles.description: To compare the deaths/cases ratio of the most left and right-leaning states.
articles.contents:
For the first graphs, I’ll compare the most left-leaning state’s
performance to that of the most right-leaning one during the beginning
of the pandemic. According to worldpopulationreview, Hawaii is the most
blue state, and Wyoming is the most red state. I’ll use those for my
comparison.



The graph shows that Hawaii’s cases have started to peak, and are
curving downwards.



Here, you can see that the line curves upwards, and shows that the
cases for Wyoming are increasing.
Analysis
The two graphs show that Hawaii did slightly better than Wyoming at
the start of the pandemic, as it had less deaths with the same amount of
cases as Wyoming.
(Disease Control and Prevention 2022)



Disease Control, Centers for, and Prevention. 2022. United States
COVID-19 Cases and Deaths by State over Time. Centers for Disease
Control and Prevention. https://data.cdc.gov/Case-Surveillance/United-States-COVID-19-Cases-and-Deaths-by-State-o/9mfq-cb36.

articles.title: Final Project
articles.description: Welcome to my final project for the datascience bootcamp!
articles.contents:
For my project, I’m going to use the data from the CDC. Here’s the
tibble that I’m going to be using:

# A tibble: 53,520 × 15
   submission_date state tot_cases conf_cases prob_cases new_case
   <chr>           <chr>     <dbl>      <dbl>      <dbl>    <dbl>
 1 12/22/2021      DE       165076     151750      13326      662
 2 03/18/2021      NE       206980         NA         NA      298
 3 09/01/2021      ND       118491     107475      11016      536
 4 03/28/2022      VT       107785         NA         NA      467
 5 03/11/2021      MD       390490         NA         NA      924
 6 04/21/2022      ID       445350     348949      96401        0
 7 02/02/2021      IL      1130917    1130917          0     2304
 8 12/13/2020      MD       234647         NA         NA     2638
 9 06/15/2020      WI        25480      22932       2548      185
10 03/10/2020      CA          157        157          0       24
# … with 53,510 more rows, and 9 more variables: pnew_case <dbl>,
#   tot_death <dbl>, conf_death <dbl>, prob_death <dbl>,
#   new_death <dbl>, pnew_death <dbl>, created_at <chr>,
#   consent_cases <chr>, consent_deaths <chr>

With this table, we can access a large amount of data on COVID-19.
For example, I can access information about total cases and deaths, as
well as daily stats.
